Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for the 30th IEEE Computer Security Foundations Symposium (CSF); August, 2017, Santa Barbara, CA

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal supports student travel to attend the 2017 Computer Security Foundations Symposium (CSF) to be held in Santa Barbara, California, August 2017. CSF is an annual conference for researchers in computer security, to examine current theories of security, the formal models that provide a context for those theories, and techniques for verifying security. This travel grant will enable career development and learning opportunities for US-based and/or US citizen graduate students. Attending conferences is an important component of graduate school education for our society's future computer security researchers. Students have the opportunity to discuss leading edge research with world-class computer security researchers, and establish networks, connections, and mentoring relationships that will serve them well during their research careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This travel grant supported 8 US-based graduate students to attend the 30th IEEE Computer Security Foundations Symposium (CSF 2017). Attending the symposium enabled career development and learning opportunities for these graduate students, and helped educate and nurture a new generation of researchers that will address important and foundational problems in computer security. 


CSF 2017 was held in Santa Barbara, CA, August 2017, co-located with CRYPTO17. It had two affiliated workshops: Foundations of Computer Security (FCS), and Graphical Models in Security (GraMSec). CSF received 94 paper submissions, of which 32 were accepted (a 34% acceptance rate). In addition to presentations for each of the accepted papers, the program included keynote talks by prominent foundational security researchers (Martín Abadi, Cédric Fournet, and Elaine Shi), and a 5-minute talk session (where attendees present research highlights). CSF 2017 had 82 attendees, of which 37 were US-based (i.e., indicated affiliation with a US institution). Other countries represented by attendees include Austria, Belgium, China, Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, Portugal, South Korea, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, The Netherlands, and the United Kingdom.

The Computer Security Foundations Symposium (CSF) is an annual conference for researchers in computer security, to examine current theories of security, the formal models that provide a context for those theories, and techniques for verifying security. More details on the history of the symposium, can be found in the CSF home page http://www.ieee-security.org/CSFWweb/.
